div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Arragon comes
this night to Messina.

sp.speaker: Messengers
sp.ab: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off
when I left him.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: But few of any sort, and none of name.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings
home full numbers. I find here that Don Pedro
hath bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called
Claudio.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: Much deserved on his part and equally remembered
by Don Pedro; he hath borne himself beyond the
promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a
lamb, the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better
bettered expectation than you must expect of me to
tell you how.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much
glad of it.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: I have already delivered him letters, and there
appears much joy in him; even so much that joy
could not show itself modest enough without a badge of
bitterness.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Did he break out into tears?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: In great measure.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces
truer than those that are so washed. How much better
is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the
wars or no?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such in
the army of any sort.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: What is he that you ask for, niece?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever he was.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged
Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading
the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged
him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath
he killed and eaten in these wars? But how many
hath he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of
his killing.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much; but
he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat
it: he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an
excellent stomach.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: And a good soldier too, lady.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a
lord?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all
honourable virtues.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man:
but for the stuffing, well, we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a
kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and
her: they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit
between them.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict
four of his five wits went halting off, and now
is the whole man governed with one: so that if
he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him
bear it for a difference between himself and his
horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath
left, to be known a reasonable creature. Who is
his companion now? He hath every month a new sworn
brother.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as
the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the next
block.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: No; an he were, I would burn my study. But, I
pray you, who is his companion? Is there no young
squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the
devil?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he
is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the
taker runs presently mad. God help the noble
Claudio! if he have caught the Benedick, it will cost
him a thousand pound ere 'a be cured.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: I will hold friends with you, lady.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Do, good friend.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: You will never run mad, niece.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: No, not till a hot January.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: Don Pedro is approached.
sp.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Good Signior Leonato, are you come to meet your
trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid cost,
and you encounter it.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness
of your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort
should remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow
abides and happiness takes his leave.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is
your daughter.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Her mother hath many times told me so.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this
what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers
herself. Be happy, lady; for you are like an
honourable father.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not
have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as
like him as she is.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior
Benedick: nobody marks you.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Is it possible disdain should die while she hath
such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?
Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come
in her presence.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain
I am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and
I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard
heart; for, truly, I love none.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: A dear happiness to women: they would else have
been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank
God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for
that: I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a
man swear he loves me.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so
some gentleman or other shall scape a predestinate
scratched face.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere such a
face as yours were.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue,
and so good a continuer. But keep your way, a' God's
name; I have done.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio
and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath
invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here
at the least a month; and he heartily prays some
occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no
hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.
Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to
the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Please it your grace lead on?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.
sp.stage: Exeunt all except Benedick and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior
Leonato?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Is she not a modest young lady?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Do you question me, as an honest man should do,
for my simple true judgement; or would you have
me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant
to their sex?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgement.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high
praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little
for a great praise: only this commendation I can
afford her, that were she other than she is, she
were unhandsome; and being no other but as she is, I
do not like her.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me truly
how thou likest her.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Can the world buy such a jewel?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you
this with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting
Jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and
Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man
take you, to go in the song?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I
looked on.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no
such matter: there's her cousin, an she were not
possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in
beauty as the first of May doth the last of
December. But I hope you have no intent to turn
husband, have you?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the
contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world
one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?
Shall I never see a bachelor of threescore again?
Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust thy
neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh
away Sundays. Look; Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: What secret hath held you here, that you followed not
to Leonato's?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a
dumb man; I would have you think so; but, on my
allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He
is in love. With who? now that is your grace's
part. Mark how short his answer is: With Hero,
Leonato's short daughter.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If this were so, so were it uttered.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Like the old tale, my lord: âit is not so, nor
'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be
so.â

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should
be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well
worthy.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: By my troth, I speak my thought.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke
mine.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: That I love her, I feel.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: That she is worthy, I know.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: That I neither feel how she should be loved nor
know how she should be worthy, is the opinion
that fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at
the stake.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of
beauty.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And never could maintain his part but in the force of
his will.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she
brought me up, I likewise give her most humble
thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in
my forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible
baldrick, all women shall pardon me. Because I
will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I
will do myself the right to trust none; and the
fine is, for the which I may go the finer, I will live
a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my
lord, not with love: prove that ever I lose more
blood with love than I will get again with
drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's
pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel-house for
the sign of blind Cupid.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou
wilt prove a notable argument.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot
at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on the
shoulder, and called Adam.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Well, as time shall try:
sp.l: âIn time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.â

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible
Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and
set them in my forehead: and let me be vilely
painted, and in such great letters as they write
âHere is good horse to hire,â let them signify
under my sign âHere you may see Benedick the married
man.â

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice,
thou wilt quake for this shortly.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I look for an earthquake too, then.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Well, you will temporize with the hours. In the
meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to
Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will
not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made great
preparation.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I have almost matter enough in me for such an
embassage; and so I commit you

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse
is sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards
are but slightly basted on neither: ere you flout
old ends any further, examine your conscience: and so
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: My liege, your highness now may do me good.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: No child but Hero; she's his only heir.
Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O, my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I looked upon her with a soldier's eye,
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am returned and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant, in their rooms
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Thou wilt be like a lover presently
And tire the hearer with a book of words.
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,
And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: How sweetly you do minister to love,
That know love's grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity.
Look, what will serve is fit; 'tis once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy.
I know we shall have revelling to-night:
I will assume thy part in some disguise
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after to her father will I break;
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.
In practice let us put it presently. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: How now, brother! Where is my cousin, your son? hath
he provided this music?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell you
strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Are they good?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: As the event stamps them: but they have a good
cover; they show well outward. The prince and
Count Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley
in mine orchard, were thus much overheard by a
man of mine: the prince discovered to Claudio
that he loved my niece your daughter and meant
to acknowledge it this night in a dance; and if
he found her accordant, he meant to take the
present time by the top and instantly break with you
of it.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and question
him yourself.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear
itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal,
that she may be the better prepared for an answer,
if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell
her of it.
Cousins, you know what you have to do. O, I cry
you mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will
use your skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy
time.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out of
measure sad?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds;
therefore the sadness is without limit.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: You should hear reason.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: If not a present remedy, at least a patient
sufferance.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayest thou
art, born under Saturn, goest about to apply a
moral medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot
hide what I am: I must be sad when I have cause
and smile at no man's jests, eat when I have
stomach and wait for no man's leisure, sleep when
I am drowsy and tend on no man's business, laugh when
I am merry and claw no man in his humour.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Yea, but you must not make the full show of this
till you may do it without controlment. You have
of late stood out against your brother, and he
hath ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is
impossible you should take true root but by the
fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful
that you frame the season for your own harvest.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose
in his grace, and it better fits my blood to be
disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to
rob love from any: in this, though I cannot be
said to be a flattering honest man, it must not
be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am
trusted with a muzzle and enfranchised with a
clog; therefore I have decreed not to sing in my
cage. If I had my mouth, I would bite; if I had
my liberty, I would do my liking: in the meantime let
me be that I am and seek not to alter me.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Can you make no use of your discontent?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I make all use of it, for I use it only. Who comes
here?
What news, Borachio?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: I came yonder from a great supper: the prince
your brother is royally entertained by Leonato:
and I can give you intelligence of an intended
marriage.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Will it serve for any model to build mischief
on? What is he for a fool that betroths himself to
unquietness?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Even he.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks he?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Marry, one Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking
a musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio,
hand in hand, in sad conference: I whipped me
behind the arras; and there heard it agreed upon
that the prince should woo Hero for himself, and
having obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Come, come, let us thither: this may prove food
to my displeasure. That young start-up hath all
the glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him
any way, I bless myself every way. You are both sure,
and will assist me?

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: To the death, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the
greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were a' my
mind! Shall we go prove what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: We'll wait upon your lordship.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Was not Count John here at supper?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: I saw him not.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him
but I am heart-burned an hour after.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: He were an excellent man that were made just in
the midway between him and Benedick: the one is
too like an image and says nothing, and the other too
like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count
John's mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in
Signior Benedick's face,

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money
enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in
the world, if 'a could get her good will.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a
husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: In faith, she's too curst.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen
God's sending that way; for it is said, âGod
sends a curst cow short horns;â but to a cow too curst
he sends none.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Just, if he send me no husband; for the which
blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning
and evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband
with a beard on his face: I had rather lie in the
woollen.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel
and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath
a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath
no beard is less than a man: and he that is more
than a youth is not for me, and he that is less
than a man, I am not for him: therefore I will
even take sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and
lead his apes into hell.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Well, then, go you into hell?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: No, but to the gate; and there will the devil
meet me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his
head, and say âGet you to heaven, Beatrice, get
you to heaven; here's no place for you maids:â
so deliver I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter
for the heavens; he shows me where the bachelors sit,
and there live we as merry as the day is long.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled by your father.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy
and say âFather, as it please you.â But yet for
all that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow,
or else make another curtsy and say âFather, as it
please me.â

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a
husband.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Not till God make men of some other metal than
earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered
with a piece of valiant dust? to make an account
of her life to a clod of wayward marl? No, uncle,
I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren; and, truly, I
hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince do
solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you
be not wooed in good time: if the prince be too
important, tell him there is measure in every
thing and so dance out the answer. For, hear me,
Hero: wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a
Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace: the
first suit is hot and hasty, like a Scotch jig,
and full as fantastical; the wedding, mannerly-modest,
as a measure, full of state and ancientry; and
then comes repentance and, with his bad legs,
falls into the cinquepace faster and faster, till he
sink into his grave.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by
daylight.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.
sp.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA, and others, masked.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say
nothing, I am yours for the walk; and especially when
I walk away.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: With me in your company?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: I may say so, when I please.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: And when please you to say so?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: When I like your favour; for God defend the lute
should be like the case!

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Speak low, if you speak love.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: Well, I would you did like me.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many ill
qualities.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: Which is one?

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: I say my prayers aloud.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: God match me with a good dancer!

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: Amen.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is
done! Answer, clerk.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: No more words: the clerk is answered.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: I know you by the waggling of your head.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: You could never do him so ill-well, unless you
were the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down:
you are he, you are he.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.ab: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by
your excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? Go
to, mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's
an end.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Will you not tell me who told you so?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: No, you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Not now.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good
wit out of the âHundred Merry Tales:â well, this was
Signior Benedick that said so.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: What's he?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I am sure you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Not I, believe me.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Did he never make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I pray you, what is he?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Why, he is the prince's jester: a very dull fool;
only his gift is in devising impossible slanders:
none but libertines delight in him; and the
commendation is not in his wit, but in his
villainy; for he both pleases men and angers
them, and then they laugh at him and beat him.
I am sure he is in the fleet: I would he had boarded
me.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on
me; which, peradventure not marked or not laughed
at, strikes him into melancholy; and then there's
a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no
supper that night.
We must follow the leaders.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: In every good thing.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the
next turning.
sp.stage: Dance. Then exeunt all except Don John, Borachio, and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath
withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The
ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Are not you Signior Benedick?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: You know me well; I am he.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Signior, you are very near my brother in his
love: he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade
him from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may
do the part of an honest man in it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: How know you he loves her?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I heard him swear his affection.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her
to-night.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Come, let us to the banquet.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Thus answer I in name of Benedick,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
'Tis certain so; the prince woos for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love:
Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues;
Let every eye negotiate for itself
And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero! Re-enter BENEDICK.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Count Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Yea, the same.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Come, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Whither?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Even to the next willow, about your own business,
county. What fashion will you wear the garland
of? about your neck, like an usurer's chain? or
under your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You
must wear it one way, for the prince hath got your
Hero.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I wish him joy of her.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so
they sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would
have served you thus?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I pray you, leave me,

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the boy
that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into
sedges. But that my Lady Beatrice should know
me, and not know me! The prince's fool! Ha? It
may be I go under that title because I am merry.
Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong; I am
not so reputed: it is the base, though bitter,
disposition of Beatrice that puts the world into
her person, and so gives me out. Well, I'll be
revenged as I may.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Now, signior, where's the count? did you see him?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady
Fame. I found him here as melancholy as a lodge
in a warren: I told him, and I think I told him
true, that your grace had got the good will of
this young lady; and I offered him my company to
a willow-tree, either to make him a garland, as
being forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being
worthy to be whipped.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: To be whipped! What's his fault?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being
overjoyed with finding a bird's nest, shows it his
companion, and he steals it.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The
transgression is in the stealer.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made,
and the garland too; for the garland he might
have worn himself, and the rod he might have
bestowed on you, who, as I take it, have stolen his
bird's nest.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to the
owner.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you
say honestly.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the
gentleman that danced with her told her she is much
wronged by you.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block!
an oak but with one green leaf on it would have
answered her; my very visor began to assume life
and scold with her. She told me, not thinking I
had been myself, that I was the prince's jester,
that I was duller than a great thaw; huddling
jest upon jest with such impossible conveyance
upon me that I stood like a man at a mark, with
a whole army shooting at me. She speaks poniards,
and every word stabs: if her breath were as
terrible as her terminations, there were no living
near her; she would infect to the north star. I
would not marry her, though she were endowed with
all that Adam had left him before he transgressed:
she would have made Hercules have turned spit,
yea, and have cleft his club to make the fire
too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find her
the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God
some scholar would conjure her; for certainly,
while she is here, a man may live as quiet in
hell as in a sanctuary; and people sin upon
purpose, because they would go thither; so,
indeed, all disquiet, horror and perturbation follows
her.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Look, here she comes.
sp.stage: Re-enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Will your grace command me any service to the
world's end? I will go on the slightest errand
now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send
me on; I will fetch you a toothpicker now from
the furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length
of Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the
great Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the
Pigmies, rather than hold three words' conference with
this harpy. You have no employment for me?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: None, but to desire your good company.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot endure
my Lady Tongue.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of Signior
Benedick.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave
him use for it, a double heart for his single
one: marry, once before he won it of me with
false dice, therefore your grace may well say I have
lost it.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I
should prove the mother of fools. I have brought Count
Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Not sad, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: How then? sick?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Neither, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry,
nor well; but civil count, civil as an orange, and
something of that jealous complexion.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true;
though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit
is false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy
name, and fair Hero is won: I have broke with
her father, and his good will obtained: name the day
of marriage, and God give thee joy!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my
fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and all grace
say Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were
but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady,
as you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for
you and dote upon the exchange.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with
a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on
the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his ear
that he is in her heart.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And so she doth, cousin.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to
the world but I, and I am sunburnt; I may sit in a
corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I would rather have one of your father's getting.
Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you? Your
father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by
them.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Will you have me, lady?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: No, my lord, unless I might have another for
working-days: your grace is too costly to wear
every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I was
born to speak all mirth and no matter.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry
best becomes you; for, out a' question, you were born
in a merry hour.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then
there was a star danced, and under that was I born.
Cousins, God give you joy!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your grace's pardon.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: There's little of the melancholy element in her,
my lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps,
and not ever sad then; for I have heard my daughter
say, she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked
herself with laughing.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they
would talk themselves mad.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: To-morrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love
have all his rites.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a
just seven-night; and a time too brief, too, to have
all things answer my mind.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing:
but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not
go dully by us. I will in the interim undertake
one of Hercules' labours; which is, to bring
Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a
mountain of affection the one with the other. I
would fain have it a match, and I doubt not but
to fashion it, if you three will but minister such
assistance as I shall give you direction.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights'
watchings.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And I, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: And you too, gentle Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my
cousin to a good husband.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband
that I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of
a noble strain, of approved valour and confirmed
honesty. I will teach you how to humour your
cousin, that she shall fall in love with Benedick;
and I, with your two helps, will so practise on
Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and
his queasy stomach, he shall fall in love with
Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no longer
an archer: his glory shall be ours, for we are
the only love-gods. Go in with me, and I will tell you
my drift.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter
of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be
medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to
him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection
ranges evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this
marriage?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no
dishonesty shall appear in me.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Show me briefly how.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: I think I told your lordship a year since, how
much I am in the favour of Margaret, the
waiting-gentlewoman to Hero.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I remember.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night,
appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber-window.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: What life is in that, to be the death of this
marriage?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you
to the prince your brother; spare not to tell
him that he hath wronged his honour in marrying
the renowned Claudio whose estimation do you
mightily hold up to a contaminated stale, such a one
as Hero.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: What proof shall I make of that?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Proof enough to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio,
to undo Hero and kill Leonato. Look you for any other
issue?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Only to despite them, I will endeavour any thing.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Go, then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro
and the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you
know that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal
both to the prince and Claudio, as, in love of
your brother's honour, who hath made this match,
and his friend's reputation, who is thus like to
be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that
you have discovered thus. They will scarcely
believe this without trial: offer them instances;
which shall bear no less likelihood than to see
me at her chamber-window, hear me call Margaret
Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio; and bring
them to see this the very night before the intended
wedding, for in the meantime I will so fashion
the matter that Hero shall be absent, and there
shall appear such seeming truth of Hero's disloyalty
that jealousy shall be called assurance and all the
preparation overthrown.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will
put it in practice. Be cunning in the working this,
and thy fee is a thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning
shall not shame me.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Boy!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.ab: Signior?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither to
me in the orchard.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.ab: I am here already, sir.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and
here again.
I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much
another man is a fool when he dedicates his
behaviours to love, will, after he hath laughed
at such shallow follies in others, become the
argument of his own scorn by falling in love:
and such a man is Claudio. I have known when
there was no music with him but the drum and the
fife; and now had he rather hear the tabor and
the pipe: I have known when he would have walked
ten mile afoot to see a good armour; and now will
he lie ten nights awake, carving the fashion of
a new doublet. He was wont to speak plain and to
the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier;
and now is he turned orthography; his words are
a very fantastical banquet, just so many strange
dishes. May I be so converted and see with these
eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not be
sworn but love may transform me to an oyster;
but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made
an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a
fool. One woman is fair, yet I am well; another
is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous, yet I
am well; but till all graces be in one woman,
one woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she
shall be, that's certain; wise, or I'll none;
virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her; fair, or
I'll never look on her; mild, or come not near
me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse,
an excellent musician, and her hair shall be of
what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and Monsieur
Love! I will hide me in the arbour.
sp.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Come, shall we hear this music?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,
As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O, very well, my lord: the music ended,
We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth. Enter BALTHASAR with Music.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.l: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
To slander music any more than once.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: It is the witness still of excellency
To put a strange face on his own perfection.
I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.l: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos,
Yet will he swear he loves.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Nay, pray thee, come;
Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.l: Note this before my notes;
There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;
Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing. Air.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it
not strange that sheep's guts should hale souls
out of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when
all's done.

lg.l: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in sea and one on shore,
To one thing constant never:
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blithe and bonny,
Converting all your sounds of woe
Into Hey nonny, nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,
Of dumps so dull and heavy;
The fraud of men was ever so,
Since summer first was leavy:
Then sigh not so, etc.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: By my troth, a good song.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: And an ill singer, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Ha, no, no, faith; thou sing'st well enough for a
shift.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: An he had been a dog that should have howled
thus, they would have hanged him: and I pray God
his bad voice bode no mischief. I had as lief
have heard the night-raven, come what plague could
have come after it.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray
thee, get us some excellent music; for to-morrow
night we would have it at the Lady Hero's
chamber-window.

sp.speaker: Balthasar
sp.ab: The best I can, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Do so: farewell.
Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of
to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with
Signior Benedick?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: O, ay: stalk on, stalk on; the fowl sits. I did never
think that lady would have loved any man.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she
should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in
all outward behaviours seemed ever to abhor.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think
of it but that she loves him with an enraged
affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: May be she doth but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Faith, like enough.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit
of passion came so near the life of passion as she
discovers it.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard my
daughter tell you how.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: She did, indeed.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: How, how, I pray you? You amaze me: I would have
thought her spirit had been invincible against all
assaults of affection.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially against
Benedick.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I should think this a gull, but that the
white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot, sure,
hide himself in such reverence.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: 'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: âShall
I,â says she, âthat have so oft encountered him with
scorn, write to him that I love him?â

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: This says she now when she is beginning to write
to him; for she'll be up twenty times a night,
and there will she sit in her smock till she have writ
a sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty
jest your daughter told us of.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she
found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: That.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence;
railed at herself, that she should be so immodest
to write to one that she knew would flout her:
âI measure him,â says she, âby my own spirit;
for I should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though
I love him, I should.â

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,
beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; âO
sweet Benedick! God give me patience!â

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the
ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter
is sometime afeard she will do a desperate outrage to
herself: it is very true.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other,
if she will not discover it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: To what end? He would make but a sport of it and
torment the poor lady worse.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's
an excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion,
she is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And she is exceeding wise.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: In every thing but in loving Benedick.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so
tender a body, we have ten proofs to one that
blood hath the victory. I am sorry for her, as
I have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I
would have daffed all other respects and made
her half myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and
hear what 'a will say.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Were it good, think you?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says
she will die, if he love her not, and she will
die, ere she make her love known, and she will
die, if he woo her, rather than she will bate one
breath of her accustomed crossness.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: She doth well: if she should make tender of her
love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the man,
as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: He is a very proper man.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And I take him to be valiant.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of
quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he
avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes them
with a most Christian-like fear.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: If he do fear God, 'a must necessarily keep peace:
if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a
quarrel with fear and trembling.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: And so will he do; for the man doth fear God,
howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests
he will make. Well, I am sorry for your niece. Shall
we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with good
counsel.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out
first.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter:
let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and
I could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see
how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never trust
my expectation.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Let there be the same net spread for her; and
that must your daughter and her gentlewoman carry.
The sport will be, when they hold one an opinion
of another's dotage, and no such matter: that's
the scene that I would see, which will be merely
a dumb show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.
sp.stage: Exeunt Don Pedro, Claudio, and Leonato.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: This can be no trick: the conference was sadly
borne. They have the truth of this from Hero.
They seem to pity the lady: it seems her affections
have their full bent. Love me! why, it must be
requited. I hear how I am censured: they say I
will bear myself proudly, if I perceive the love
come from her: they say too that she will rather
die than give any sign of affection. I did never
think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy are
they that hear their detractions and can put them
to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a
truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous;
'tis so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for
loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her
wit, nor no great argument of her folly, for I
will be horribly in love with her. I may chance
have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken
on me, because I have railed so long against
marriage: but doth not the appetite alter? a man
loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure
in his age. Shall quips and sentences and these
paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the
career of his humour? No, the world must be
peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor, I
did not think I should live till I were married.
Here comes Beatrice. By this day! she's a fair lady: I
do spy some marks of love in her.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to
dinner.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I took no more pains for those thanks than you
take pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I
would not have come.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: You take pleasure then in the message?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's
point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach,
signior: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Ha! âAgainst my will I am sent to bid you come
in to dinner;â there's a double meaning in that.
âI took no more pains for those thanks than you
took pains to thank me;â that's as much as to
say, Any pains that I take for you is as easy as
thanks. If I do not take pity of her, I am a
villain; if I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go
get her picture.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlour;
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the prince and Claudio:
Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse
Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles, ripened by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites,
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,
To listen our propose. This is thy office;
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.l: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit:
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. Approaching the bower.
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: So says the prince and my newtrothed lord.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endeared.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: Sure, I think so;
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she'll make sport at it.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured,
But she would spell him backward: if fair-faced,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antique,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agate very vilely cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: No; rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with: one doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.
She cannot be so much without true judgement
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted my dear Claudio.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.l: She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: If it prove so, then loving goes by haps:
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps. Exeunt Hero and Ursula.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemned for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly. Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and
then go I toward Arragon.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll vouchsafe
me.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new
gloss of your marriage as to show a child his
new coat and forbid him to wear it. I will only
be bold with Benedick for his company; for, from
the crown of his head to the sole of his foot,
he is all mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut
Cupid's bow-string and the little hangman dare
not shoot at him; he hath a heart as sound as a
bell and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart
thinks his tongue speaks.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: So say I: methinks you are sadder.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I hope he be in love.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood
in him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad,
he wants money.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I have the toothache.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Draw it.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Hang it!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: What! sigh for the toothache?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Where is but a humour or a worm.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Yet say I, he is in love.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless
it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises;
as, to be a Dutchman to-day, a Frenchman to-morrow,
or in the shape of two countries at once, as, a
German from the waist downward, all slops, and
a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet. Unless
he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears
he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it
appear he is.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If he be not in love with some woman, there is
no believing old signs: 'a brushes his hat o'
mornings; what should that bode?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him,
and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed
tennis-balls.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a
beard.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Nay, 'a rubs himself with civet: can you smell him out
by that?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: And when was he wont to wash his face?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear what
they say of him.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into a
lute-string and now governed by stops.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,
conclude he is in love.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Nay, but I know who loves him.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: That would I know too: I warrant one that knows him
not.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of all,
dies for him.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old
signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight
or nine wise words to speak to you, which these
hobby-horses must not hear.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this
played their parts with Beatrice; and then the
two bears will not bite one another when they meet.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: My lord and brother, God save you!

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Good den, brother.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: In private?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for what
I would speak of concerns him.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Means your lordship to be married to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: You know he does.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: You may think I love you not: let that appear
hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now
will manifest. For my brother, I think he holds
you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to
effect your ensuing marriage, surely suit ill spent
and labour ill bestowed.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances
shortened, for she has been too long a-talking of, the
lady is disloyal.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Who, Hero?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Disloyal?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness;
I could say she were worse: think you of a worse
title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till
further warrant: go but with me to-night, you
shall see her chamber-window entered, even the
night before her wedding-day: if you love her
then, to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your
honour to change your mind.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: May this be so?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I will not think it.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not
that you know: if you will follow me, I will show
you enough; and when you have seen more and heard
more, proceed accordingly.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If I see any thing to-night why I should not
marry her to-morrow, in the congregation, where I
should wed, there will I shame her.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join
with thee to disgrace her.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: I will disparage her no farther till you are my
witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and let
the issue show itself.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: O day untowardly turned!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: O mischief strangely thwarting!

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.ab: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when
you have seen the sequel.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Are you good men and true?

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer
salvation, body and soul.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them,
if they should have any allegiance in them, being
chosen for the prince's watch.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: First, who think you the most desartless man to be
constable?

sp.speaker: First Watch
sp.ab: Hugh Oatcake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can
write and read.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed
you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man
is the gift of fortune: but to write and read comes by
nature.

sp.speaker: Second Watch
sp.ab: Both which, master constable,

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well,
for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and
make no boast of it; and for your writing and
reading, let that appear when there is no need
of such vanity. You are thought here to be the
most senseless and fit man for the constable of
the watch; therefore bear you the lantern. This
is your charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom
men; you are to bid any man stand, in the prince's
name.

sp.speaker: Second Watch
sp.ab: How if 'a will not stand?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go;
and presently call the rest of the watch together and
thank God you are rid of a knave.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of
the prince's subjects.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: True, and they are to meddle with none but the
prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise
in the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to
talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: We will rather sleep than talk; we know what belongs
to a watch.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet
watchman; for I cannot see how sleeping should
offend: only, have a care that your bills be not
stolen. Well, you are to call at all the ale-houses,
and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: How if they will not?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober:
if they make you not then the better answer, you may
say they are not the men you took them for.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by
virtue of your office, to be no true man; and,
for such kind of men, the less you meddle or make with
them, why, the more is for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands
on him?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled: the most
peaceable way for you, if you do take a thief,
is to let him show himself what he is and steal out of
your company.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a
man who hath any honesty in him.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call to
the nurse and bid her still it.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child
wake her with crying; for the ewe that will not
hear her lamb when it baes will never answer a calf
when he bleats.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: This is the end of the charge: you, constable,
are to present the prince's own person: if you meet
the prince in the night, you may stay him.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Nay, by'r lady, that I think 'a cannot.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Five shillings to one on't, with any man that
knows the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not
without the prince be willing; for, indeed, the
watch ought to offend no man; and it is an offence to
stay a man against his will.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: By'r lady, I think it be so.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there
be any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep
your fellows' counsels and your own; and good night.
Come, neighbour.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit
here upon the church-bench till two, and then all to
bed.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you,
watch about Signior Leonato's door; for the
wedding being there to-morrow, there is a great coil
to-night. Adieu: be vigitant, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: What, Conrade!

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: Peace! stir not.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Conrade, I say!

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Here, man; I am at thy elbow.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Mass, and my elbow itched; I thought there would a
scab follow.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: I will owe thee an answer for that: and now forward
with thy tale.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse,
for it drizzles rain; and I will, like a true
drunkard, utter all to thee.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: Some treason, masters: yet stand close.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand
ducats.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any
villainy should be so rich; for when rich villains
have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price
they will.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest
that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak,
is nothing to a man.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Yes, it is apparel.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: I mean, the fashion.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool. But seest
thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is?

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: I know that Deformed; 'a has been a vile thief
this seven year; 'a goes up and down like a gentleman:
I remember his name.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Didst thou not hear somebody?

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: No; 'twas the vane on the house.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this
fashion is? how giddily 'a turns about all the
hot-bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty?
sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers
in the reechy painting, sometime like god Bel's
priests in the old church-window, sometime like
the shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten
tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his
club?

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: All this I see; and I see that the fashion wears
out more apparel than the man. But art not thou
thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou
hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the
fashion?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Not so, neither: but know that I have to-night
wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by
the name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress'
chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good
night, I tell this tale vilely: I should first
tell thee how the prince, Claudio and my master,
planted and placed and possessed by my master
Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable
encounter.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Two of them did, the prince and Claudio; but the
devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly
by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly
by the dark night, which did deceive them, but
chiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any
slander that Don John had made, away went Claudio
enraged; swore he would meet her, as he was
appointed, next morning at the temple, and there,
before the whole congregation, shame her with
what he saw o'ernight and send her home again without
a husband.

sp.speaker: Second Watch
sp.ab: We charge you, in the prince's name, stand!

sp.speaker: First Watch
sp.ab: Call up the right master constable. We have here
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that
ever was known in the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Second Watch
sp.ab: And one Deformed is one of them: I know him; 'a wears
a lock.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Masters, masters,

sp.speaker: First Watch
sp.ab: You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Masters,

sp.speaker: Second Watch
sp.ab: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with
us.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken
up of these men's bills.

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we'll
obey you.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her
to rise.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: I will, lady.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: And bid her come hither.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: Well.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Troth, I think your other rabato were better.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: By my troth's not so good; and I warrant your cousin
will say so.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: My cousin's a fool, and thou art another: I'll wear
none but this.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: I like the new tire within excellently, if the
hair were a thought browner; and your gown's a
most rare fashion, i' faith. I saw the Duchess of
Milan's gown that they praise so.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: O, that exceeds, they say.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: By my troth's but a night-gown in respect of
yours: cloth a' gold, and cuts, and laced with
silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side
sleeves, and skirts, round underborne with a
bluish tinsel: but for a fine, quaint, graceful and
excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on't.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is exceeding
heavy.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not
marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord
honourable without marriage? I think you would
have me say, âsaving your reverence, a husband:â
and bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll
offend nobody: is there any harm in âthe heavier
for a husbandâ? None, I think, an it be the right
husband and the right wife: otherwise 'tis light,
and not heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else; here she
comes.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: Good morrow, coz.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: Why, how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Clap's into âLight a' love;â that goes without a
burden: do you sing it, and I'll dance it.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Ye light a' love, with your heels! then, if your
husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall lack
no barns.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my
heels.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: 'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; 'tis time you
were ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill: heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: For the letter that begins them all, H.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Well, and you be not turned Turk, there's no more
sailing by the star.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: What means the fool, trow?

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's
desire!

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: These gloves the count sent me; they are an excellent
