perfume.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I am stuffed, cousin; I cannot smell.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly catching of cold.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: O, God help me! God help me! how long have you
professed apprehension?

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Ever since you left it. Doth not my wit become me
rarely?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your cap.
By my troth, I am sick.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Get you some of this distilled Carduus Benedictus,
and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a
qualm.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Benedictus! why Benedictus? you have some moral in
this Benedictus.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning;
I meant, plain holy-thistle. You may think
perchance that I think you are in love: nay, by'r
lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list,
nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed
I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of
thinking, that you are in love or that you will
be in love or that you can be in love. Yet Benedick
was such another, and now is he become a man: he
swore he would never marry, and yet now, in
despite of his heart, he eats his meat without
grudging: and how you may be converted I know
not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other
women do.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Not a false gallop.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: Madam, withdraw: the prince, the count, Signior
Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town,
are come to fetch you to church.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 5
div.stage: Enter LEONATO, with DOGBERRY and VERGES.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that
decerns you nearly.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a busy time with
me.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Marry, this it is, sir.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: What is it, my good friends?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the
matter: an old man, sir, and his wits are not so
blunt as, God help, I would desire they were;
but, in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living that
is an old man and no honester than I.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Neighbours, you are tedious.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are
the poor duke's officers; but truly, for mine
own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find
in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis;
for I hear as good exclamation on your worship
as of any man in the city; and though I be but a poor
man, I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: I would fain know what you have to say.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Marry, sir, our watch to-night, excepting your
worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant
knaves as any in Messina.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: A good old man, sir; he will be talking: as they
say, When the age is in, the wit is out: God help
us! it is a world to see. Well said, i' faith,
neighbour Verges: well, God's a good man; an two
men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An
honest soul, i' faith, sir; by my troth he is,
as ever broke bread; but God is to be worshipped; all
men are not alike; alas, good neighbour!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Gifts that God gives.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: One word, sir: our watch, sir, have indeed
comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would have
them this morning examined before your worship.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Take their examination yourself and bring it me:
I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: It shall be suffigance.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.ab: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to
her husband.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: I'll wait upon them: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole;
bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the gaol: we are
now to examination these men.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: And we must do it wisely.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you; here's
that shall drive some of them to a noncome: only
get the learned writer to set down our excommunication
and meet me at the gaol.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, HERO, BEATRICE, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Come, Friar Francis, be brief; only to the plain
form of marriage, and you shall recount their
particular duties afterwards.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.ab: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: No.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: To be married to her: friar, you come to marry her.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.ab: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: I do.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.ab: If either of you know any inward impediment why
you should not be conjoined, I charge you, on your
souls, to utter it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Know you any, Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.ab: None, my lord.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.ab: Know you any, count?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: I dare make his answer, none.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: O, what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily
do, not knowing what they do!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: How now! interjections? Why, then, some be of
laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Stand thee by, friar. Father, by your leave:
Will you with free and unconstrained soul
Give me this maid, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: And what have I to give you back, whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Nothing, unless you render her again.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Sweet prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.
There, Leonato, take her back again:
Give not this rotten orange to your friend;
She's but the sign and semblance of her honour.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O, what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,
All you that see her, that she were a maid,
By these exterior shows? But she is none:
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: What do you mean, my lord?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof,
Have vanquished the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginity,

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the 'forehand sin:
No, Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large;
But, as a brother to his sister, showed
Bashful sincerity and comely love.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it:
You seem to me as Dian in her orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown;
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus, or those pampered animals
That rage in savage sensuality.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Sweet prince, why speak not you?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: What should I speak?
I stand dishonoured, that have gone about
To link my dear friend to a common stale.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.l: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: This looks not like a nuptial.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: True! O God!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the prince? is this the prince's brother?
Is this face Hero's? are our eyes our own?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: All this is so: but what of this, my lord?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Let me but move one question to your daughter;
And, by that fatherly and kindly power
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: O, God defend me! how am I beset!
What kind of catechising call you this?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: To make you answer truly to your name.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Marry, that can Hero;
Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue.
What man was he talked with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Why, then are you no maiden. Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear: upon mine honour,
Myself, my brother and this grieved count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber-window
Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,
Confessed the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.l: Fie, fie! they are not to be named, my lord,
Not to be spoke of;
There is not chastity enough in language
Without offence to utter them. Thus, pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been,
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! farewell,
Thou pure impiety and impious purity!
For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love,
And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me? Hero swoons.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?

sp.speaker: Don John
sp.l: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up. Exeunt Don Pedro, Don John, and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: How doth the lady?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Dead, I think. Help, uncle!
Hero! why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand.
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wished for.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: How now, cousin Hero!

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Have comfort, lady.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Dost thou look up?

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Yea, wherefore should she not?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?
Do not live, Hero; do not ope thine eyes:
For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,
Strike at thy life. Grieved I, I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal nature's frame?
O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar's issue at my gates,
Who smirched thus and mired with infamy,
I might have said âNo part of it is mine;
This shame derives itself from unknown loinsâ?
But mine and mine I loved and mine I praised
And mine that I was proud on, mine so much
That I myself was to myself not mine,
Valuing of her â why, she, O, she is fallen
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Sir, sir, be patient.
For my part, I am so attired in wonder,
I know not what to say,

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: O, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: No, truly not; although, until last night,
I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Confirmed, confirmed! O, that is stronger made
Which was before barred up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so, that, speaking of her foulness,
Washed it with tears? Hence from her! let her die.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Hear me a little;
For I have only been silent so long
And given way unto this course of fortune
By noting of the lady. I have marked
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes;
And in her eye there hath appeared a fire,
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool;
Trust not my reading nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenor of my book; trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
Under some biting error.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Friar, it cannot be.
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury; she not denies it:
Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: They know that do accuse me; I know none:
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy! O my father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintained the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Two of them have the very bent of honour;
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practice of it lives in John the bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I know not. If they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honour,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,
Nor age so eat up my invention,
Nor fortune made such havoc of my means,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb and policy of mind,
Ability in means and choice of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Your daughter here the princes left for dead:
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it that she is dead indeed;
Maintain a mourning ostentation
And on your family's old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: What shall become of this? what will this do?

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf
Change slander to remorse; that is some good:
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth.
She dying, as it must be so maintained,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied and excused
Of every hearer: for it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost,
Why, then we rack the value, then we find
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio:
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
The idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely organ of her life
Shall come apparelled in more precious habit,
More moving delicate and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul,
Than when she lived indeed; then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her,
No, though he thought his accusation true.
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be levelled false,
The supposition of the lady's death
Will quench the wonder of her infamy:
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds and injuries.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you:
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in this
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: 'Tis well consented: presently away;
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.
Come, lady, die to live: this wedding-day
Perhaps is but prolonged: have patience and endure. Exeunt all but Benedick and Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Yea, and I will weep awhile longer.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I will not desire that.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: You have no reason; I do it freely.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would
right her!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Is there any way to show such friendship?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: A very even way, but no such friend.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: May a man do it?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: It is a man's office, but not yours.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I do love nothing in the world so well as you: is not
that strange?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: As strange as the thing I know not. It were as
possible for me to say I loved nothing so well
as you: but believe me not; and yet I lie not;
I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sorry for
my cousin.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Do not swear, and eat it.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I will swear by it that you love me; and I will make
him eat it that says I love not you.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Will you not eat your word?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I
love thee.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Why, then, God forgive me!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: What offence, sweet Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: You have stayed me in a happy hour: I was about to
protest I loved you.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: And do it with all thy heart.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left
to protest.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Come, bid me do any thing for thee.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Kill Claudio.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Ha! not for the wide world.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I am gone, though I am here: there is no love in you:
nay, I pray you, let me go.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Beatrice,

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: In faith, I will go.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: We'll be friends first.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with
mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Is Claudio thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Is 'a not approved in the height a villain, that
hath slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman?
O that I were a man! What, bear her in hand until
they come to take hands; and then, with public
accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated
rancour, â O God, that I were a man! I would eat his
heart in the marketplace.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Hear me, Beatrice,

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Nay, but, Beatrice,

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Sweet Hero! She is wronged, she is slandered, she is
undone.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Beat

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Princes and counties! Surely, a princely testimony,
a goodly count, Count Comfect; a sweet gallant,
surely! O that I were a man for his sake! or that
I had any friend would be a man for my sake! But
manhood is melted into curtsies, valour into
compliment, and men are only turned into tongue,
and trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules
that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be
a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with
grieving.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged
Hero?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Enough, I am engaged; I will challenge him. I
will kiss your hand, and so I leave you. By this
hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account. As
you hear of me, so think of me. Go, comfort your
cousin: I must say she is dead: and so, farewell.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and Sexton, in gowns; and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: O, a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: Which be the malefactors?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Marry, that am I and my partner.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Nay, that's certain; we have the exhibition to
examine.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: But which are the offenders that are to be examined?
let them come before master constable.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Yea, marry, let them come before me. What is your
name, friend?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Borachio.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Pray, write down, Borachio. Yours, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Write down, master gentleman Conrade. Masters, do you
serve God?

sp.speaker: Conrade and Borachio
sp.ab: Yea, sir, we hope.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Write down, that they hope they serve God: and
write God first; for God defend but God should
go before such villains! Masters, it is proved
already that you are little better than false
knaves; and it will go near to be thought so shortly.
How answer you for yourselves?

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Marry, sir, we say we are none.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: A marvellous witty fellow, I assure you: but I
will go about with him. Come you hither, sirrah;
a word in your ear: sir, I say to you, it is thought
you are false knaves.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Sir, I say to you we are none.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Well, stand aside. 'Fore God, they are both in a tale.
Have you writ down, that they are none?

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: Master constable, you go not the way to examine:
you must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Yea, marry, that's the eftest way. Let the watch
come forth. Masters, I charge you, in the prince's
name, accuse these men.

sp.speaker: First Watch
sp.ab: This man said, sir, that Don John, the prince's
brother, was a villain.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat
perjury, to call a prince's brother villain.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Master constable,

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Pray thee, fellow, peace: I do not like thy look, I
promise thee.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: What heard you him say else?

sp.speaker: Second Watch
sp.ab: Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don
John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Yea, by mass, that it is.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: What else, fellow?

sp.speaker: First Watch
sp.ab: And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words,
to disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not
marry her.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: O villain! thou wilt be condemned into everlasting
redemption for this.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: What else?

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.ab: This is all.

sp.speaker: Sexton
sp.ab: And this is more, masters, than you can deny.
Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away;
Hero was in this manner accused, in this very
manner refused, and upon the grief of this suddenly
died. Master constable, let these men be bound,
and brought to Leonato's: I will go before and show
him their examination.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Come, let them be opinioned.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Let them be in the hands

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Off, coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: God's my life, where's the sexton? let him write
down the prince's officer coxcomb. Come, bind them.
Thou naughty varlet!

sp.speaker: Conrade
sp.ab: Away! you are an ass, you are an ass.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Dost thou not suspect my place? dost thou not
suspect my years? O that he were here to write
me down an ass! But, masters, remember that I am
an ass; though it be not written down, yet forget
not that I am an ass. No, thou villain, thou art
full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by
good witness. I am a wise fellow, and, which is
more, an officer, and, which is more, a householder,
and, which is more, as pretty a piece of flesh
as any is in Messina, and one that knows the law,
go to; and a rich fellow enough, go to; and a
fellow that hath had losses, and one that hath
two gowns and every thing handsome about him. Bring
him away. O that I had been writ down an ass!

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself:
And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I pray thee, cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless
As water in a sieve: give not me counsel;
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,
And bid him speak of patience;
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form:
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
And, sorrow wag, cry âhem!â when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk
With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience.
But there is no such man: for, brother, men
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion, which before
Would give preceptial medicine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air and agony with words:
No, no; 'tis all men's office to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel:
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood;
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently,
However they have writ the style of gods
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself;
Make those that do offend you suffer too.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: There thou speak'st reason: nay, I will do so.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the prince
And all of them that thus dishonour her.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Here comes the prince and Claudio hastily. Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Good den, good den.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Good day to both of you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Hear you, my lords,

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: We have some haste, Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Some haste, my lord! well, fare you well, my lord:
Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: If he could right himself with quarrelling,
Some of us would lie low.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Who wrongs him?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou:
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword;
I fear thee not.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Marry, beshrew my hand,
If it should give your age such cause of fear:
In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Tush, tush, man; never fleer and jest at me:
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag
What I have done being young, or what would do
Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,
Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me
That I am forced to lay my reverence by
And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days,
Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child;
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors;
O, in a tomb where never scandal slept,
Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: My villainy?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: You say not right, old man.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: My lord, my lord,
I'll prove it on his body, if he dare,
Despite his nice fence and his active practice,
His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Away! I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast killed my child:
If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed:
But that's no matter; let him kill one first;
Win me and wear me; let him answer me.
Come, follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come, follow me:
Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence;
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Brother,

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece;
And she is dead, slandered to death by villains,
That dare as well answer a man indeed
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue:
Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Brother Anthony,

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,
Scambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys,
That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,
Go anticly, and show outward hideousness,
And speak off half a dozen dangerous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst;
And this is all.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: But, brother Anthony,

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Come, 'tis no matter:
Do not you meddle; let me deal in this.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
My heart is sorry for your daughter's death:
But, on my honour, she was charged with nothing
But what was true and very full of proof.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: My lord, my lord,

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: And shall, or some of us will smart for it. Exeunt Leonato and Antonio

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: See, see; here comes the man we went to seek. Enter BENEDICK.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Now, signior, what news?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Good day, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Welcome, signior: you are almost come to part almost a
fray.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: We had liked to have had our two noses snapped off
with two old men without teeth.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Leonato and his brother. What thinkest thou? Had
we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for
them.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: In a false quarrel there is no true valour. I came to
seek you both.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: We have been up and down to seek thee; for we
are high-proof melancholy and would fain have it
beaten away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: It is in my scabbard: shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Never any did so, though very many have been
beside their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the
minstrels; draw, to pleasure us.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: As I am an honest man, he looks pale. Art thou sick,
or angry?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: What, courage, man! What though care killed a cat,
thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and
you charge it against me. I pray you choose another
subject.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Nay, then, give him another staff: this last was broke
cross.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: By this light, he changes more and more: I think he be
angry indeed.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: God bless me from a challenge!

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: You are a villain; I jest not: I will make it
good how you dare, with what you dare, and when
you dare. Do me right, or I will protest your
cowardice. You have killed a sweet lady, and her death
shall fall heavy on you. Let me hear from you.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: What, a feast, a feast?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I' faith, I thank him; he hath bid me to a
calf's-head and a capon; the which if I do not
carve most curiously, say my knife's naught. Shall I
not find a woodcock too?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the
other day. I said, thou hadst a fine wit: âTrue,â
said she, âa fine little one.â âNo,â said I, âa
great wit:â âRight,â says she, âa great gross
one.â âNay,â said I, âa good wit:â âJust,â said
she, âit hurts nobody.â âNay,â said I, âthe
gentleman is wise:â âCertain,â said she, âa wise
gentleman.â âNay,â said I, âhe hath the tongues:â
âThat I believe,â said she, âfor he swore a thing
to me on Monday night, which he forswore on
Tuesday morning; there's a double tongue; there's
two tongues.â Thus did she, an hour, together,
transshape thy particular virtues: yet at last
she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the properest man
in Italy.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: For the which she wept heartily and said she cared
not.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Yea, that she did: but yet, for all that, an if
she did not hate him deadly, she would love him
dearly: the old man's daughter told us all.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: All, all; and, moreover, God saw him when he was hid
in the garden.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the
sensible Benedick's head?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Yea, and text underneath, âHere dwells Benedick the
married manâ?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Fare you well, boy: you know my mind. I will
leave you now to your gossiplike humour: you
break jests as braggards do their blades, which
God be thanked, hurt not. My lord, for your many
courtesies I thank you: I must discontinue your
company: your brother the bastard is fled from
Messina: you have among you killed a sweet and
innocent lady. For my Lord Lackbeard there, he
and I shall meet: and, till then, peace be with him.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: He is in earnest.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: In most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for
the love of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: And hath challenged thee.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet
and hose and leaves off his wit.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a
doctor to such a man.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: But, soft you, let me be: pluck up, my heart, and be
sad. Did he not say, my brother was fled?
sp.stage: Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Come you, sir: if justice cannot tame you, she
shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance:
nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be
looked to.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: How now? two of my brother's men bound! Borachio one!

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Hearken after their offence, my lord.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Officers, what offence have these men done?

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Marry, sir, they have committed false report;
moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily,
they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have
belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust
things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly,
I ask thee what's their offence; sixth and lastly,
why they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay
to their charge.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: Rightly reasoned, and in his own division: and, by my
troth, there's one meaning well suited.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.ab: Who have you offended, masters, that you are thus
bound to your answer? this learned constable is too
cunning to be understood: what's your offence?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Sweet prince, let me go no farther to mine answer:
do you hear me, and let this count kill me. I
have deceived even your very eyes: what your
wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools
have brought to light: who in the night overheard
me confessing to this man how Don John your
brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero,
how you were brought into the orchard and saw me
court Margaret in Hero's garments, how you
disgraced her, when you should marry her: my
villainy they have upon record; which I had rather
seal with my death than repeat over to my shame.
The lady is dead upon mine and my master's false
accusation; and, briefly, I desire nothing but the
reward of a villain.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: But did my brother set thee on to this?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.ab: Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: He is composed and framed of treachery:
And fled he is upon this villainy.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Sweet Hero! now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by this time
our sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the
matter: and, masters, do not forget to specify, when
time and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

sp.speaker: Verges
sp.ab: Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the
Sexton too.
sp.stage: Re-enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, with the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes,
That, when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him: which of these is he?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.l: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed
Mine innocent child?

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.l: Yea, even I alone.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: No, not so, villain; thou beliest thyself:
Here stand a pair of honourable men;
A third is fled, that had a hand in it.
I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death:
Record it with your high and worthy deeds:
'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I know not how to pray your patience;
Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself;
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin: yet sinned I not
But in mistaking.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: By my soul, nor I:
And yet, to satisfy this good old man,
I would bend under any heavy weight
That he'll enjoin me to.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live;
That were impossible: but, I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here
How innocent she died; and if your love
Can labour aught in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb
And sing it to her bones, sing it to-night:
To-morrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that's dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us:
Give her the right you should have given her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: O noble sir,
Your overkindness doth wring tears from me!
I do embrace your offer; and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: To-morrow then I will expect your coming;
To-night I take my leave. This naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

sp.speaker: Borachio
sp.l: No, by my soul, she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous
In any thing that I do know by her.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white
and black, this plaintiff here, the offender,
did call me ass: I beseech you, let it be remembered
in his punishment. And also, the watch heard them
talk of one Deformed: they say he wears a key in
his ear and a lock hanging by it, and borrows
money in God's name, the which he hath used so
long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted
and will lend nothing for God's sake: pray you,
examine him upon that point.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverend
youth; and I praise God for you.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: There's for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: God save the foundation!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank
thee.

sp.speaker: Dogberry
sp.ab: I leave an arrant knave with your worship; which
I beseech your worship to correct yourself, for
the example of others. God keep your worship! I
wish your worship well; God restore you to health!
I humbly give you leave to depart; and if a merry
meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! Come,
neighbour.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Farewell, my lords: we look for you to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: To-night I'll mourn with Hero.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Bring you these fellows on. We'll talk with Margaret,
How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow. Exeunt, severally.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well
at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my
beauty?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living
shall come over it; for, in most comely truth, thou
deservest it.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: To have no man come over me! why, shall I always keep
below stairs?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth; it
catches.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit,
but hurt not.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: A most manly wit, Margaret; it will not hurt a
woman: and so, I pray thee, call Beatrice: I give thee
the bucklers.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the
pikes with a vice; and they are dangerous weapons for
maids.

sp.speaker: Margaret
sp.ab: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath
legs.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: And therefore will come.

lg.l: The god of love,
That sits above,
And knows me, and knows me,
How pitiful I deserve,

sp.ab: I mean in singing; but in loving, Leander the
good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of
panders, and a whole bookful of these quondam
carpet-mongers, whose names yet run smoothly in
the even road of a blank verse, why, they were
never so truly turned over and over as my poor
self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in rhyme;
I have tried: I can find out no rhyme to âladyâ
but âbaby,â an innocent rhyme; for âscorn,â
âhorn,â a hard rhyme; for, âschool,â âfool,â a
babbling rhyme; very ominous endings: no, I was
not born under a rhyming planet, nor I cannot woo in
festival terms.
Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Yea, signior, and depart when you bid me.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: O, stay but till then!

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: âThenâ is spoken; fare you well now: and yet,
ere I go, let me go with that I came; which is,
with knowing what hath passed between you and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Only foul words; and thereupon I will kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is
but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome; therefore
I will depart unkissed.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right
sense, so forcible is thy wit. But I must tell
thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge;
and either I must shortly hear from him, or I
will subscribe him a coward. And, I pray thee
now, tell me for which of my bad parts didst thou
first fall in love with me?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: For them all together; which maintained so politic
a state of evil that they will not admit any good
part to intermingle with them. But for which of my
good parts did you first suffer love for me?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Suffer love! a good epithet! I do suffer love indeed,
for I love thee against my will.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: In spite of your heart, I think; alas, poor heart!
If you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for
yours; for I will never love that which my friend
hates.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: It appears not in this confession: there's not
one wise man among twenty that will praise himself.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in
the time of good neighbours. If a man do not
erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he
shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings
and the widow weeps.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: And how long is that, think you?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Question: why, an hour in clamour and a quarter
in rheum: therefore is it most expedient for the
wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, find no
impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of
his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for
praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness,
is praiseworthy: and now tell me, how doth your
cousin?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Very ill.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: And how do you?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Very ill too.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Serve God, love me and mend. There will I leave you
too, for here comes one in haste.

sp.speaker: Ursula
sp.ab: Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder's old
coil at home: it is proved my Lady Hero hath been
falsely accused, the prince and Claudio mightily
abused; and Don John is the author of all, who is fled
and gone. Will you come presently?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: Will you go hear this news, signior?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap and be buried
in thy eyes; and moreover
I will go with thee to thy uncle's.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and three or four with tapers.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Is this the monument of Leonato?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: It is, my lord.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Done to death by slanderous tongues
Was the Hero that here lies:
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies.
So the life that died with shame
Lives in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dumb.
Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.

lg.l: Pardon, goddess of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight;
For the which, with songs of woe,
Round about her tomb they go.
Midnight, assist our moan;
Help us to sigh and groan,
Heavily, heavily:
Graves, yawn and yield your dead,
Till death be uttered,
Heavily, heavily.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Now, unto thy bones good night!
Yearly will I do this rite.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Good morrow, masters; put your torches out:
The wolves have preyed; and look, the gentle day,
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
Thanks to you all, and leave us: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Good morrow, masters: each his several way.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds;
And then to Leonato's we will go.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: And Hymen now with luckier issue speed's
Than this for whom we rendered up this woe. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, BENEDICK, BEATRICE, MARGARET, URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, and HERO.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: So are the prince and Claudio, who accused her
Upon the error that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will, as it appears
In the true course of all the question.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Well, I am glad that all things sorts so well.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: And so am I, being else by faith enforced
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you, come hither masked. Exeunt Ladies.
The prince and Claudio promised by this hour
To visit me. You know your office, brother:
You must be father to your brother's daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: Which I will do with confirmed countenance.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: To do what, signior?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: To bind me, or undo me; one of them.
Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: That eye my daughter lent her: 'tis most true.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio and the prince: but what's your will?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical:
But, for my will, my will is your good will
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoined
In the state of honourable marriage:
In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: My heart is with your liking.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: And my help.
Here comes the prince and Claudio. Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO, and two or three others.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Good morrow, prince; good morrow, Claudio;
We here attend you. Are you yet determined
to-day to marry with my brother's daughter?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I'll hold my mind, were she an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Call her forth, brother; here's the friar ready. Exit Antonio.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter,
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
Tush, fear not, man; we'll tip thy horns with gold
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Jove,
When he would play the noble beast in love.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low;
And some such strange bull leaped your father's cow,
And got a calf in that same noble feat
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings. Re-enter ANTONIO, with the Ladies masked.
Which is the lady I must seize upon?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.l: This same is she, and I do give you her.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Why, then she's mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: No, that you shall not, till you take her hand
Before this friar and swear to marry her.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Give me your hand: before this holy friar,
I am your husband, if you like of me.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: And when I lived, I was your other wife: Unmasking.
And when you loved, you were my other husband.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: Another Hero!

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: Nothing certainer:
One Hero died defiled, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.

sp.speaker: Friar
sp.l: All this amazement can I qualify;
When after that the holy rites are ended,
I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death:
Meantime let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: I answer to that name. What is your will?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Why, no; no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Why, then your uncle and the prince and Claudio
Have been deceived; they swore you did.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: Troth, no; no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: Why, then my cousin Margaret and Ursula
Are much deceived; for they did swear you did.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.l: 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.l: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.l: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.l: And I'll be sworn upon't that he loves her;
For here's a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashioned to Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Hero
sp.l: And here's another
Writ in my cousin's hand, stolen from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedick.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: A miracle! here's our own hands against our
hearts. Come, I will have thee; but, by this light, I
take thee for pity.

sp.speaker: Beatrice
sp.ab: I would not deny you; but, by this good day, I
yield upon great persuasion; and partly to save your
life, for I was told you were in a consumption.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Peace! I will stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Don Pedro
sp.l: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: I'll tell thee what, prince; a college of
wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humour.
Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram?
No: if a man will be beaten with brains, 'a shall
wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since
I do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to
any purpose that the world can say against it;
and therefore never flout at me for what I have
said against it; for man is a giddy thing, and
this is my conclusion. For thy part, Claudio, I
did think to have beaten thee; but in that thou
art like to be my kinsman, live unbruised and love my
cousin.

sp.speaker: Claudio
sp.ab: I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice,
that I might have cudgelled thee out of thy single
life, to make thee a double-dealer; which, out
of question, thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look
exceeding narrowly to thee.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Come, come, we are friends: let's have a dance
ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts
and our wives' heels.

sp.speaker: Leonato
sp.ab: We'll have dancing afterward.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: First, of my word; therefore play, music. Prince,
thou art sad; get thee a wife, get thee a wife:
there is no staff more reverend than one tipped with
horn.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight,
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

sp.speaker: Benedick
sp.ab: Think not on him till to-morrow: I'll devise thee
brave punishments for him. Strike up, pipers.
